tossups.question: This hero accidentally killed the super-hospitable King Kyzikos on his wedding night after his escape from six-armed "Earthborn" giants brought this man back to the city of the Doliones. It's not Theseus, but a companion of this hero foiled Talos's attack on him by disorienting the automaton using keres (KAY-ress) spirits. This subject of epics by Valerius Flaccus and Apollonius of Rhodes successfully plowed a field with the fire-breathing Khalkotauroi on a mission given to this hero after he lost a sandal while carrying a disguised Hera across a river. Integral to that quest was a talking piece of wood from Dodona and the love of a daughter of Aietes. For 10 points, name this hero, the beloved of Medea who sought the Golden Fleece with the Argonauts.

During an attack on this city, people crowded into the Church of the Tithes, only for the balcony to collapse, killing many. This was the most important city taken by Grand Duke Algirdas after the Battle of Blue Waters. The aforementioned Christian church was built after the people in this city were baptized and threw a statue of Perun into the river. This city was sacked in 1240, shortly after they killed Mongke's envoys, angering Batu Khan, and Sviatopolk the Accursed seized power in this city, probably by killing his three brothers. It was the capital of a state ruled by men like Vladimir I and Yaroslav the Wise, who were also princes of Novgorod. For 10 points, name this city that from 882 to 1240 served as the capital of the Rus (ROOS), and which currently is located in Ukraine.

When constructing the Born–Haber cycle for potassium chloride, the only exothermic steps in the cycle are the step corresponding to this value for chlorine, and the "lattice energy" step involving the condensation of gaseous ions into the lattice. Chemical hardness can be approximated by one-half the difference between ionization energy and this quantity. This value increases for elements from left to right across a period, but there are many anomalies; its values for nitrogen and beryllium are negative and thus smaller than for carbon and lithium due to a stability conferred by half-filled or filled orbitals. For 10 points, name this quantity equal to negative the standard molar enthalpy of electron gain for a gaseous monatomic element.
tossups.answer: electron affinity [accept lattice energy or lattice enthalpy until read] <Pendyala>

tossups.question: This painting was completed with the help of the artist's brother Benedetto Caliari, who is shown inspecting a glass. No person in this painting is shown speaking, possibly alluding to the code of silence followed by its Benedictine commissioners. A digitally produced copy of this painting hangs in the refectory of San Giorgio Maggiore, where it was displayed before its seizure by Napoleon's army. The musicians at this painting's center are modeled on its artist and three Venetian contemporaries. This largest painting in the Louvre shows several real-life rulers, like Charles V and Suleiman the Magnificent, seated at banquet tables. For 10 points, name this painting by Paolo Veronese of the event where Jesus turned water into wine.
tossups.answer: The Wedding at Cana [or The Wedding Feast at Cana] <Shimizu>

tossups.question: Two answers required. A Newsweek letter writer punningly suggested that we "Locke up" one of these men and give the other "Descartes blanche." In a 1971 speech, in explaining his lack of response to the other, one of these men recalled receiving a "55-page" missive "by someone I had never heard of." One of these men's students, Kenneth MacCorquodale, defended him from the other in a 1970 paper. The feud between these two men centered on the question of whether a certain skill is learned or innate, which arose after one of them wrote a scathing 1959 review for the journal Language that ripped into the other's book, Verbal Behavior; that review promoted cognitive psychology at the expense of behaviorism. For 10 points, name these two men, the psychologist author of Walden Two and the linguist author of Syntactic Structures.
tossups.answer: Burrhus Frederic Skinner AND Avram Noam Chomsky [accept in either order] <Cheyne>

tossups.question: After being threatened with torture, a guard in this play asks a king whether his pain lies in his soul or in his ears. In this play, a man is accused of taking bribes after he recounts how birds screamed and clawed at each other so he could not make out their language. A chorus in this play declares, "Wonders are many, and none are more wonderful than man," prior to the arrest of the protagonist. In this play, Haemon lunges at his father then stabs himself after discovering his bride has hanged herself in a cave. This play's title character defies Creon's edict that no one shall give proper burial rites to her brother Polynices. For 10 points, name this Sophocles play about the daughter of Oedipus.

A Prime Minister from this party raised eyebrows by giving peerages to those on the "Lavender List," including several businessmen thought to be corrupt. The alleged "Clockwork Orange" campaign was supposedly directed against a Prime Minister from this party, who, according to the book Spycatcher, was thought to be a foreign agent. A Welsh member of this party was the controversial Aneurin Bevan. An economist from it chaired the group that produced the Beveridge Report, leading to the eventual creation of the National Health Service under this party. For 10 points, Harold Wilson and Clement Attlee were members of what British political party, which took power from Winston Churchill's Conservatives in 1945?

Myf5 and Mrf4 promote precursor differentiation into this tissue. Receptors in this tissue are the primary targets of pancuronium and other curare mimetics. Repair of this non-glial tissue depends on proliferation and fusion of its quiescent satellite cells to produce new multinucleated cells. End plate potentials induce ion release through RyR1, or ryanodine receptor type 1, at sites in this tissue. Nm-type nicotinic receptors in this tissue respond to A-c-h released at NMJs. Its slow-twitch fibers contain less sarcoplasmic reticulum than fast-twitch fibers, but are able to contract for longer periods. For 10 points, name this striated tissue that can be voluntarily controlled, unlike smooth and cardiac muscle.
tossups.answer: skeletal muscle [prompt on muscle or striated muscle] <Smart>

tossups.question: In one film role, this actor's character is memorialized with the lines "He was some kind of man. What does it matter what you say about people?" That was a reference to this actor's role as corrupt cop Hank Quinlan. In another film role, this man's character notes that Switzerland's "five hundred years of democracy and peace" only produced the "cuckoo clock." That character of this actor refers to people below a ferris wheel as "dots" and is a criminal named Harry Lime. This man played antagonists in the films Touch of Evil and The Third Man. In an early film role, he plays a publisher based on William Randolph Hearst who enigmatically says the word "Rosebud" as he dies. For 10 points, name this man who played the title character in a 1941 film he also directed, Citizen Kane.

In this novel's 11th chapter, "The Arched Window," a character is horrified by the greed of an organ grinder's performing monkey. A laborer in this novel forces a young girl named Alice to walk through snow wearing just an evening gown, resulting in her death from pneumonia. Throughout this novel, its main characters tirelessly search for the deed to a huge claim of land in Maine. The daguerreotypist Holgrave recounts the history of this novel's central family, whose ancestor is afflicted with the curse "God will give him blood to drink" after hanging Matthew Maule. A portrait of that 17th-century judge haunts Phoebe and Hepzibah, who live in this novel's title structure. For 10 points, name this Gothic novel about the Pyncheon family, written by Nathaniel Hawthorne.
tossups.answer: The House of the Seven Gables <Belal>

tossups.question: In 1950, Hilary Koprowski tested an early version of this thing at Letchworth Village. Basil O'Connor defended the use of a version of this thing by saying it went through unprecedented tests for safety. The contaminated production of this thing at Cutter Labs in 1955 resulted in five deaths. In 1956, Thomas Francis Jr. of the University of Michigan proclaimed the success of this thing in a broadcast funded by Eli Lilly and Company. An oral version of this thing was developed by Albert Sabin, who was opposed by the March of Dimes Foundation, which supported the work of another researcher. For 10 points, Jonas Salk developed the first effective form of what drug that prevented the spreading of an infectious disease that paralyzed many children?
tossups.answer: polio vaccine [or poliomyelitis vaccine; accept any answers about something that prevents polio] <Cheyne>

tossups.question: The Laughlin wavefunction is used to study this effect for filling factors of one over an odd integer. Composite fermions were introduced to study this effect. It occurs when electrons are confined to two dimensions and very cold temperatures and when B-fields are strong enough that Landau levels become degenerate enough so that free electrons remain in only a few levels. This effect demonstrates the quantization of conductance in terms of e-squared over h, and it occurs in integer and fractional varieties. For 10 points, name this effect discovered by Klaus von Klitzing, which is analogous to an effect from classical electrodynamics in which a voltage is produced transverse to an electric current and an applied magnetic field.
tossups.answer: quantum Hall effect [or fractional quantum Hall effect; or integer quantum Hall effect; prompt on Hall effect] <Overman>

tossups.question: A character with this name is tasked by the Devil to plow 60 acres in half a day, but is helped by the Devil's daughter and his future wife, Lilith. That character with this name returned to his homeland, but left behind a namesake "root" popular among hoodoo magic users. A legendary African prince who was sold as a slave in America but was renowned for his wit had this name and was known as the "Conqueror." This was the name of the descendant of the Three Magi whose kingdom was legendarily in places like India or Ethiopia. That ruler with this name was sought by Crusaders, who believed he would help them defeat Muslims. For 10 points, what name was held by a mythical Christian king with the title of "Prester"?
tossups.answer: John [or John the Conqueror; or John de Conquer; or Prester John; prompt on Prester until read] <Cheyne>

tossups.question: Michael Reynolds was told to produce photographs of this event. On the morning of this event, a planned, multi-year performance art exhibition was set up at the Museum of the Moving Image by the team of Luke Turner, Nastja Sade Ronkko, and Shia LeBeouf. The Interior Department briefly shut down its Twitter account following this event amid accusations that its agencies were going rogue. The coining of the phrase "alternative facts" originated from discussions about this event. During it, a man defiantly said "from this day forward, it's going to be only America first!" Sean Spicer's assertion that this event featured the largest audience of its kind is almost certainly untrue. For 10 points, name this January 20, 2017, event that officially marked the beginning of the term of the 45th President of the United States.

In one of this man's poems, the aristocratic speaker notes, "It is so late that the dew soaks my gauze stockings" as she waits for her unfaithful lover. The speaker of another poem by this author observes that by the gate the different mosses have grown "too deep to clear them away," and that "the paired butterflies are already yellow with August." This author of "The Jewel Stairs' Grievance" wrote "Lifting my head, I watch the bright moon, lowering my head, I dream that I'm home" in his short poem "Quiet Night Thoughts." Ezra Pound translated two of this man's poems, including one he called "The River-Merchant's Wife: A Letter." For 10 points, name this Tang dynasty poet who wrote "Drinking Alone by Moonlight."
tossups.answer: Li Bai [or Li Bo; or Li Po; or Rihaku] <Casalaspi>

tossups.question: During the 2008 running of this event, many objected to the use of Randwick Racecourse in Sydney. Ramzi Yousef's Bojinka Plot intended to assassinate a leader during the 1995 iteration of this event, which featured millions crowded into Luneta Park. This event typically runs every three years and will take place in Panama in 2019. Its most recent iteration, in 2016, was held at Krakow, Poland. In 1995, this event featured five million attendees, a then-record for the largest number of people gathered for a religious event. Pope Benedict expressed dismay that this event was viewed as some sort of "rock festival." For 10 points, name this international event organized by the Catholic Church for young people of all nations.

A leader of this country reassured Europeans by saying its leaders were "sane, rational people even in our moments of anguish." A leader of this country sued former colleague Devan Nair for calling him a "self-righteous know-it-all." In the 1970s, it produced numerous posters telling parents to "stop at two" children. This country banned Wired magazine after a 1993 article by William Gibson calling it "Disneyland with the Death Penalty," and American Michael Fay faced a harsh penalty for committing vandalism here. Under the leadership of its first Prime Minister, Lee Kuan Yew, this country emphasized harsh corporal punishments, such as caning. For 10 points, name this country at the southern tip of the Malaysian peninsula.

This ensemble plays Johan de Meij's (YO-han de MAY's) "Lord of the Rings" Symphony. A six-movement piece for this ensemble includes movements called "Lord Melbourne" and "Rufford Park Poachers." Ralph Vaughan Williams quoted the folk songs "Dives and Lazarus" and "Seventeen Come Sunday" in the first movement of a suite for this ensemble. Percy Grainger composed Lincolnshire Posy for this ensemble. Gustav Holst originally composed his "Fantasia on the Dargason" for the second of his two suites for this ensemble, which are in E-flat and F. John Philip Sousa led this type of ensemble, for which he composed marches like "The Stars and Stripes Forever." For 10 points, name this type of large ensemble that generally does not have a string section.
tossups.answer: concert band [or military band; or symphonic band; or marching band; or wind band; or wind ensemble] <Magin>

tossups.question: A man in this play who was interrupted while trying to kill an animal claims to have exterminated only half of a rat. A character in this play repeatedly asks for his dog, which culminates in his companion taking a toy dog and using it to strike him in the head. At the start of this play, a character pulls back the curtains to reveal a window that faces the sea and a window that faces the land. Two characters in this play lament their inability to kiss because they are buried in dirt, have no mobility, and live in dustbins. This play's two main characters, one of whom cannot sit and the other of whom cannot stand, are named Hamm and Clov. For 10 points, name this Samuel Beckett play whose title refers to the final part of a chess match.

This body contains a so-called "mountain in a moat" whose origin is unknown. This body's large system of northwest–southeast canyons includes Macross Chasma (KAZ-muh) and Serenity Chasma, in addition to Tardis Chasma, which bisects Gallifrey Macula. In 2016, scientists announced that a large dark area informally known as "Mordor" near the north pole of this body contains a cap composed of organic macromolecules called tholins, which are believed to have been formed by the reaction of compounds transferred to this body by its parent body, with which it is gravitationally locked. This moon is almost half the size of its parent body, and the two orbit their mutual barycenter, which was one reason that this moon's parent body was stripped of planet status. For 10 points, identify this largest moon of Pluto.

The Berezinian is an operation acting on the "super" form of these things. In representation theory, these objects are used in correspondence with group elements. The symplectic group is defined with these objects as its elements, as is the general linear group. In multivariable calculus, one of these objects is used in an analogue to the second derivative test, while another is used to evaluate integrals after a change of basis; those examples are the Hessian and Jacobian. Elementary operations can be used to put these objects in reduced row echelon form. Formulas derived from cofactor expansion, such as a times d minus b times c, compute these objects' determinants. For 10 points, identify these two-dimensional arrays of numbers.

bonuses.leadin: One object supposedly holding this distinction was created by Francis A. Johnson. For 10 points each:
answer: world's biggest ball of twine [or largest ball of twine]
parts: What distinction is claimed by various oddball tourist attractions, including an object located in Cawker City, Kansas, and one in Darwin, Minnesota, that weighs over 17,000 pounds?

The world's largest nylon twine ball is located in this city's Ripley's Believe It or Not Museum. Dolly Parton's Dixie Stampede and a massive Titanic replica and museum are found in this tourist trap in southern Missouri.

Another Titanic museum and a different Dolly Parton property, Dollywood, are also found in this state's eastern city of Pigeon Forge. Elvis Presley's estate of Graceland is located on the other side of this state, in Memphis.

bonuses.leadin: Bob Livingston withdrew his candidacy for this position in 1998 after the revelation that he had an affair. For 10 points each:
answer: Speaker of the House of Representatives
William Jefferson "Bill" Clinton [or William Jefferson Blythe III]
parts: Name this position. The man who obtained it after Livingston withdrew was himself sentenced to prison in 2016 after revelations that he had sexually molested boys while working as a wrestling coach.
Livingston said he withdrew his candidacy to be Speaker because he felt the revelation of his affair would harm attempts by the Republicans to impeach this President noted for his own sexual affairs.

In an attempt to challenge what he perceived as hypocrisy, this man offered one million dollars to anyone who could produce unflattering sexual stories about the Republicans. He was shot in 1978 and is now permanently paralyzed.

bonuses.leadin: Minor characters in this novel include Darius, who claims that a random cloud in the sky is God. For 10 points each:
answer: Mexican-American [or Chicana; or Chicano; prompt on Latina or Latino; prompt on Hispanic]
carnival [prompt on festival; do not accept "circus"] <Droge>
parts: Name this coming of age novel about Esperanza Cordero, a Latina girl who desires to escape the title location in Chicago.

The author of The House on Mango Street, Sandra Cisneros, is an American writer of this ethnicity. A program that studies the literature of authors of this ethnicity was controversially shut down in Tucson, Arizona.
In a controversial passage in The House on Mango Street, Esperanza is abandoned by her friend Sally and sexually assaulted during one of these events.

bonuses.leadin: Isotelus rex is the largest of these organisms ever discovered, measuring 27 inches long. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these Paleozoic arthropods found in the Burgess Shale that are often used as index fossils. They are named for having three sections.

The largest known arthropod is Jaekelopterus (juh-KLOP-tur-us), an extinct eight-foot-long one of these marine organisms. E. remipes, one of these arachnid-like animals, is the state fossil of New York.
Both trilobites and eurypterids (yoo-RIP-tuh-rids) died out at the end of this period. The largest mass extinction is named for this period and the following period.

bonuses.leadin: This activity is appealing to a man partially because he sees how "impulse was converted into momentary figures." For 10 points each:
answer: the Nazi party [or the National Socialist German Workers' Party; or the NSDAP]
parts: Name this activity that Robert Faehmel performs each weekday beginning at 9:30 in the Prince Heinrich Hotel. Faehmel is the protagonist of a German author's novel.
Robert Faehmel is the protagonist of Heinrich Boll's Billiards at Half-Past Nine. In the book, Robert refused to take "the Host of the Beast," meaning he opposed this real-life political party.

A key image in the novel is that of this structure, which was built by Robert's father, Heinrich, and then destroyed by Robert while serving in the army during World War II. At the end of the novel, the family eats from a cake modeled after this building.

bonuses.leadin: The original parts of this work were the "Codex," "Digest," and "Institutes." For 10 points each:
answer: Corpus Juris Civilis [prompt on partial answers; prompt on but DO NOT REVEAL Code of Justinian]
parts: Name this collection of laws and juristic writings issued from 529 to 534 by a certain emperor. The project that produced this work was directed by Tribonian.
The Corpus was produced during the reign of this Byzantine ruler known as the "Great," who was married to Theodora and supervised the construction of the Hagia Sophia.
A new legal code, the "Ecloga," was later implemented by this Byzantine ruler, who was known as the Isaurian and noted for his firm support of iconoclasm.

bonuses.leadin: This man used his hometown as the basis for the setting of his novel, Eclipse. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this author of a 1938 anti-war novel in which the protagonist, Joe Bonham, loses his arms, legs, and face while fighting in World War I.
After becoming a screenwriter, Trumbo was a victim of the Hollywood blacklist that prevented members, former members, or those suspected of being a member of this party from working.
This group of filmmakers, which included Trumbo, Ring Lardner Jr., and Lester Cole, was blacklisted after they refused to testify before the House of Representatives in 1947.

bonuses.leadin: This term describes points where the rank of the Jacobian is not maximal. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this term from calculus that is used to describe points where the derivative is equal to zero, and sometimes also to refer to endpoints and points where the derivative does not exist. Points described by this term are candidates for extrema.

The Gauss–Lucas (loo-KAH) theorem guarantees that the critical points of a polynomial function lie inside this set with respect to the polynomial's roots. Given any set of points, this set is defined as the smallest convex set containing all of the points.

This method developed by Leonid Khachiyan was used to show that linear programs could be solved in polynomial time. It works by enclosing the maxima inside its namesake shapes as their volumes decrease to 0.

bonuses.leadin: Sandy Koufax observed this holiday by not playing in Game 1 of the 1965 World Series. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this holiest day of the year in Judaism, the Day of Atonement that completes the period of the High Holy Days that begins with Rosh Hashanah.
At the beginning of the evening service on Yom Kippur, this declaration is recited in the synagogue. Its name means "all vows," which refers to its annulment of all personal oaths made to God.
Ashkenazi Jews who are married men wear this white linen robe on Yom Kippur. It can also serve as a burial robe.

bonuses.leadin: The quodlibet Il sera pour vous by Antoine Busnois (boon-WAH) is based on this melody. For 10 points each:
answer: Josquin des Prez (joe-SCAN deh PRAY) [prompt on des Prez]
parts: Name this secular tune popular in the 15th and 16th centuries. Scholars disagree as to whether Busnois or Guillaume du Fay was the first composer to write a cantus firmus mass based on this tune.
This Franco-Flemish composer of the Missa pange lingua is best known for his two masses based on the "L'homme armé" melody.

Josquin's Missa l'homme armé super voces musicales makes heavy use of the mensuration type of this imitative musical technique. It titles a D major chamber piece that Johann Pachelbel paired with a gigue (zheeg).

bonuses.leadin: A panel of the Isenheim Altarpiece depicts a sufferer of this disease, since it was commissioned by a monastic order specifically founded to treat it. For 10 points each:
answer: LSD [or lysergic acid diethylamide; or acid]
parts: Name this disease that spreads through fungus-infected rye and was often called "Saint Anthony's fire" during the Middle Ages. It may have been responsible for the behavior of the supposed Salem witches, since many of its symptoms are convulsive.
This hallucinogenic drug was first produced by Albert Hofmann from ergotamine, the chemical that causes ergotism's symptoms. It was controversially administered as part of the CIA's Project MKUltra.

Various 20th-century grain-related deaths were caused not by ergotism, but by fungicides containing this element. A vaccine preservative in which this element bonds with a thiol group was incorrectly claimed to have caused an increased rate of autism.

bonuses.leadin: This term is named for a Hellenistic writer who claimed to have found an inscription on an island in the Indian Ocean revealing the gods to have been mortal kings. For 10 points each:
answer: euhemerism (yoo-HEM-er-ism) [accept word forms; do not accept "deification"]
The Trojan War [accept Troy, Troia, Ilion, or Ilium for "Trojan"]
parts: Give this term for an approach to mythography that assumes or tries to find historical bases for mythical people and events. It can also refer to the process by which historical figures become mythical.
One of the most famous euhemerists, Heinrich Schliemann, believed ruins at Hisarlik to be evidence that this war between the Achaeans and a city led by Priam actually happened.
Schliemann thought a "vault" near Mycenae was the tomb of this man, Agamemnon's father. He cursed his namesake dynasty by killing his brother Thyestes's sons and feeding them to him.

bonuses.leadin: This poet of the 2011 collection Family Values was a favorite for Poet Laureate of the United Kingdom in 2009, but the honor went to Carol Ann Duffy. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this contemporary English poet who closed her collection Making Cocoa for Kingsley Amis with the title poem stating, "I knew it wouldn't be much of a poem / But I love the title."

Making Cocoa for Kingsley Amis contains a group of limericks summarizing this T. S. Eliot poem beginning "April is the cruelest month." The last limerick ends, "I hope you'll make sense of the notes."

Cope had previously missed out at becoming the UK's Poet Laureate in 1998, after the death of this man who had held the post from 1984. His poetry collections include The Hawk in the Rain and Birthday Letters.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about the "Condition of England" Question, for 10 points each.
parts: This author raised the "Condition of England" Question in his 1839 pamphlet "Chartism." He promoted the "great man" theory of history and wrote a popular chronicle of the French Revolution.

As part of the discontent giving rise to the "Condition of England" Question, this man's carriage was attacked in January 1817. In 1810, he publicly accused his wife, Caroline of Brunswick, of adultery and put her on trial.
In response to the "Condition of England" Question, Parliament passed one of these laws in 1834 that only allowed people to receive relief from workhouses.

bonuses.leadin: Systems with this property can exhibit the butterfly effect. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this property of a dynamical system that displays extreme sensitivity to initial conditions. The swinging Atwood machine and the double pendulum both have this property.

The behavior of chaotic systems can be displayed on one of these plots, which show the value of the attractor as a function of a namesake parameter. The features displayed on these diagrams can be of the pitchfork or period-doubling varieties.

For a chaotic system, the value of this quantity, which represents the rate of divergence of close trajectories, is positive. This value, which can be determined using Oseledets's theorem, is named for a Russian mathematician.

bonuses.leadin: This character is accompanied by his "Genius," which is his guardian angel. For 10 points each:
answer: Julius II [or Giulio II; or Giuliano della Rovere]
Erasmus of Rotterdam [or Desiderius Erasmus Roterodamus]
Niccolò Machiavelli [or Niccolò di Bernardo dei Machiavelli] <Cheyne>
parts: Name this real-life person who, in a philosophical dialogue, is barred from heaven by Saint Peter. This character then plots to use an army to invade and conquer heaven.
Julius II is the title character of the dialogue Julius Excluded from Heaven, which was written by this Dutchman, the author of Education of a Christian Prince.
In Erasmus's Education of a Christian Prince, he argues that a ruling prince should be loved, as opposed to this author of The Prince, who claimed it was better for a prince to be feared.

bonuses.leadin: In this poem, the speaker exclaims "How terrible and brief was my desire of you!" and notes, "In you the wars and the flights accumulated." For 10 points each:
answer: Pablo Neruda [or Neftali Ricardo Reyes Basoalto]
a large tuna in the market [or un gran atún en el mercado; prompt on fish] <Fulgenzi>
parts: Name this poem that begins, "The memory of you emerges from the night around me," and includes the refrain, "In you everything sank!"
Twenty Love Poems and a Song of Despair was written by this Chilean poet.
One of Neruda's Elemental Odes describes this type of animal "among the market vegetables," whom he describes as the "catafalqued king of my own ocean."

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about stores in the United States, for 10 points each.
parts: This company, the pioneer of the five-and-dime store, was the namesake of a building that was the tallest in the world from 1913 to 1930. A 1960 sit-in in Greensboro, North Carolina, originated in one of its stores.
The Woolworth Building was located in this city, which is also where Macy's department store was founded and where their flagship store remains to this day.

This man was the namesake of a massive department store in Philadelphia that contains a twelve-story atrium and a huge organ. A marketing innovator, he also served as Benjamin Harrison's Postmaster General.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about crazy productions of various operas, for 10 points each.
answer: La sonnambula [or The Sleepwalker] (by Vincenzo Bellini) <Cheyne>
parts: A 2001 English National Opera production of an opera by this composer featured drinking, drugs, and urinating on stage. The director accused opera critics of being "weird" and "prissy" after the audience booed that production of this composer's Don Giovanni.
A 1949 production of this Richard (REE-shot) Strauss opera directed by Peter Brook featured designs by Salvador Dalí and enraged audiences. This opera includes the "Dance of the Seven Veils."

American audiences booed a 2009 production of this opera that moved the setting from the Alps to New York. In this opera, the title character Amina is thought by villagers to be both a phantom and also the lover of Count Rodolfo.

bonuses.leadin: Identify the following about the artist Fitz Henry Lane, for 10 points each.
parts: Lane is best known for his paintings of these things. The only painting of one of these man-made objects by Rembrandt was stolen from the Gardner Museum in 1990.

After his death, Lane was grouped into this American art movement, which gets its name from the painters' focus on light. John I. H. Baur coined the name of this movement and included artists such as Alfred Thompson Bricher in it.
Several artists from this other school of American landscape artists, such as Albert Bierstadt, made Luminist works. This movement was founded by Thomas Cole.

bonuses.leadin: This man was the great-nephew of an explorer who lectured in America dressed like a Siberian exile to supplement his 1891 critique of Russia's penal system. For 10 points each:
answer: George F. Kennan [or George Frost Kennan]
parts: Name this man who explained reasons for Soviet noninvolvement in the IMF and the World Bank in his Long Telegram, which advocated against American cooperation with the Soviet Union in the early stages of the Cold War.

Kennan's Long Telegram originated this doctrine, which was justified in Southeast Asia by comparing its nations to falling dominoes. This doctrine aimed to limit Communism to a buffer zone surrounding the Soviet Union.

This journal published the Long Telegram under Kennan's pseudonym "X." This journal, whose early contributors included Elihu Root and W. E. B. DuBois, also originated Samuel Huntington's idea of the "clash of civilizations."
